description: A flat, green part of a plant that grows from the stem or branch.
The tough protective outer covering of the trunk, branches, and twigs of a tree.
A small, narrow river.
Tiny drops of water that form on cool surfaces at night.
A colored part of a flower that surrounds the reproductive parts.
The top layer of the earth in which plants grow.
A small green plant that grows in a carpet-like layer on wet ground.
A fine powdery substance released by flowers to fertilize other flowers.
The remains of an ancient organism preserved in rock.
The natural environment where a plant or animal lives.
A sweet liquid produced by flowers to attract pollinating insects and birds.
A cold, treeless area; it is the coldest biome.
The tidal mouth of a large river, where the tide meets the stream.
The process by which green plants use sunlight to synthesize food from carbon dioxide and water.
The production of light by living organisms.
Microscopic plants that live in watery environments, both salty and fresh.
A plant adapted to grow in dry conditions.
A class of fungi that form a zygospore during sexual reproduction.
A deep gorge, typically one with a river flowing through it.
A landform at the mouth of a river created by sediment deposits.
A long, narrow, deep inlet of the sea between high cliffs.
A very strong wind.
Pellets of frozen rain that fall in showers from cumulonimbus clouds.
A piece of land surrounded by water.
A dense, tropical forest with a heavy rainfall.
Large brown seaweeds that grow in underwater forests in shallow oceans.
A shallow body of water separated from a larger sea by barrier islands or reefs.
An area of low-lying land that is flooded in wet seasons or at high tide, and typically remains waterlogged at all times.
A sweet liquid secreted by flowers to attract pollinating insects and birds.
A fertile spot in a desert where water is found.
A large open area of grassland, especially in the Mississippi River valley.
A hard, crystalline mineral composed of silicon and oxygen atoms.
A ridge of jagged rock, coral, or sand just above or below the surface of the sea.
